column2: Then it was found that it was the Fairy Tulip in disguise of the old woman who had provided that sheltering cottage in the forest.
column3: Then it was found that it was the Fairy Tulip in disguise of the old woman who had provided that sheltering cottage in the forest.

column2: The joy of the King upon once more seeing his son can well be imagined, and the marriage of the Prince and Desiree, and Becafigue and Giroflee took place on the same day, the Fairies giving their diamond palace as their wedding present to Princess Desiree, and Fairy Tulip presenting four gold mines in the Indies to Giroflee.

column2: HANSEL AND GRETHEL
column3: HANSEL AND GRETHEL

column2: Once upon a time there dwelt near a large wood a poor wood cutter, with his wife, and two children by his former marriage, a little boy called Hansel, and a girl named Grethel.
column3: Once upon a time there dwelt near a large wood a poor wood cutter, with his wife, and two children by his former marriage, a little boy called Hansel, and a girl named Grethel.

column2: He had little enough to break or bite; and once, when there was a great famine in the land, he could hardly procure even his daily bread; and as he lay thinking in his bed one night, he sighed, and said to his wife, "What will become of us? How can we feed our children, when we have no more than we can eat ourselves?"
column3: He had little enough to break or bite; and once, when there was a great famine in the land, he could hardly procure even his daily bread; and as he lay thinking in his bed one night, he sighed, and said to his wife, "What will become of us? How can we feed our children, when we have no more than we can eat ourselves?"

column2: Know then, my husband, answered she, "we will lead them away, quite early in the morning, into the thickest part of the wood, and there make them a fire, and give them each a little piece of bread, then we will go to our work, and leave them alone, so they will not find the way home again, and we shall be freed from them."
column3: Know then, my husband, answered she, "we will lead them away, quite early in the morning, into the thickest part of the wood, and there make them a fire, and give them each a little piece of bread, then we will go to our work, and leave them alone, so they will not find the way home again, and we shall be freed from them."

column2: No, wife, replied he, "that I can never do; how can you bring your heart to leave my children all alone in the wood; for the wild beasts will soon come and tear them to pieces?"
column3: No, wife, replied he, "that I can never do; how can you bring your heart to leave my children all alone in the wood; for the wild beasts will soon come and tear them to pieces?"

column2: Oh, you simpleton! said she, "then we must all four die of hunger; you had better plane the coffins for us." But she left him no peace till he consented, saying, "Ah, but I shall miss the poor children."
column3: Oh, you simpleton! said she, "then we must all four die of hunger; you had better plane the coffins for us." But she left him no peace till he consented, saying, "Ah, but I shall miss the poor children."

column2: The two children, however, had not gone to sleep, for very hunger, and so they overheard what the stepmother said to their father.
column3: The two children, however, had not gone to sleep, for very hunger, and so they overheard what the stepmother said to their father.

column2: Grethel wept bitterly, and said to Hansel, "What will become of us?"
column3: Grethel wept bitterly, and said to Hansel, "What will become of us?"

column2: Be quiet, Grethel, said he; "do not cry--I will help you." And as soon as their parents had gone to sleep, he got up, put on his coat, and, unbarring the back door, went out.
column3: Be quiet, Grethel, said he; "do not cry-I will help you." And as soon as their parents had gone to sleep, he got up, put on his coat, and, unbarring the back door, went out.

column2: The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay before the door seemed like silver pieces, they glittered so brightly.
column3: The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay before the door seemed like silver pieces, they glittered so brightly.

column2: Hansel stooped down, and put as many into his pocket as it would hold; and then going back he said to Grethel, "Be of good cheer, dear sister, and sleep in peace; God will not forsake us." And so saying, he went to bed again.

column2: The next morning, before the sun arose, the wife went and awoke the two children.

column2: When they had gone a little distance, Hansel stood still, and peeped back at the house; and this he repeated several times, till his father said, "Hansel, what are you looking at, and why do you lag behind?

column2: Take care, and remember your legs."

column2: Ah, father, said Hansel, "I am looking at my white cat sitting upon the roof of the house, and trying to say good-bye."
column3: Ah, father, said Hansel, "I am looking at my white cat sitting upon the roof of the house, and trying to say good bye."

column2: You simpleton! said the wife, "that is not a cat; it is only the sun shining on the white chimney." But in reality Hansel was not looking at a cat; but every time he stopped, he dropped a pebble out of his pocket upon the path.

column2: When they came to the middle of the forest, the father told the children to collect wood, and he would make them a fire, so that they should not be cold.
column3: When they came to the middle of the forest, the father told the children to collect wood, and he would make them a fire, so that they should not be cold.

column2: So Hansel and Grethel gathered together quite a little mount of twigs.
column3: So Hansel and Grethel gathered together quite a little mount of twigs.

column2: Then they set fire to them; and as the flame burnt up high, the wife said, "Now, you children, lie down near the fire, and rest yourselves, whilst we go into the forest and chop more wood; when we are ready we will come and call you."
column3: Then they set fire to them; and as the flame burnt up high, the wife said, "Now, you children, lie down near the fire, and rest yourselves, whilst we go into the forest and chop more wood; when we are ready we will come and call you."

column2: Hansel and Grethel sat down by the fire, and when it was noon, each ate the piece of bread; and because they could hear the blows of an axe they thought their father was near; but it was not an axe, but a branch which he had bound to an old tree, so as to be blown to and fro by the wind.

column2: They waited so long, that at last their eyes closed from weariness, and they fell fast asleep.
column3: They waited so long, that at last their eyes closed from weariness, and they fell fast asleep.

column2: When they awoke, it was quite dark, and Grethel began to cry.
column3: When they awoke, it was quite dark, and Grethel began to cry.

column2: How shall we get out of the wood? But Hansel tried to comfort her by saying, "Wait a little while till the moon rises, and then we will quickly find the way." column3: How shall we get out of the wood? But Hansel tried to comfort her by saying, "Wait a little while till the moon rises, and then we will quickly find the way." column2: All night long they walked on, and as day broke they came to their father's house.

column2: We thought you were never coming home again." But their father was extremely glad, for it had grieved his heart to leave them all alone.

column2: Not long afterwards there was again great scarcity in every corner of the land; and one night the children overheard their mother saying to their father, "Everything is once more consumed; we have only half a loaf left, and then the song is ended: the children must be sent away. We will take them deeper into the wood, so that they may not find the way out again; it is the only means of escape for us."
column3: Not long afterwards there was again great scarcity in every corner of the land; and one night the children overheard their mother saying to their father, "Everything is once more consumed; we have only half a loaf left, and then the song is ended: the children must be sent away. We will take them deeper into the wood, so that they may not find the way out again; it is the only means of escape for us."

column2: But her husband felt heavy at heart, and thought, "It were better to share the last crust with the children." His wife, however, would listen to nothing that he said, and scolded and reproached him without end.

column3: Nevertheless he comforted Grethel, saying, "Do not weep; sleep in quiet; the good God will not forsake us."

column2: Hansel, why do you stop and look about? said the father, "keep in the path." "I am looking at my little dove," answered Hansel, "nodding a good-bye to me." "Simpleton!" said the wife, "that is no dove, but only the sun shining on the chimney." But Hansel kept still dropping crumbs as he went along.

column2: The mother led the children deep into the wood, where they had never been before, and there making a gigantic fire, she said to them, "Sit down here and rest, and when you feel tired you can sleep for a little while.
column3: The mother led the children deep into the wood, where they had never been before, and there making a gigantic fire, she said to them, "Sit down here and rest, and when you feel tired you can sleep for a little while.

column2: We are going into the forest to hew wood, and in the evening, when we are ready, we will come and fetch you again."

column2: When noon came, Grethel shared her bread with Hansel, who had strewn his on the path.

column2: They then went to sleep; but the evening arrived and no one came to visit the poor children, and in the dark night they awoke, and Hansel comforted his sister by saying, "Only wait, Grethel, till the moon comes out, then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have dropped, and they will show us the way home." The moon shone and they got up, but they could not see any crumbs, for the thousands of birds which had been flying about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

The moon shone and they got up, but they could not see any crumbs, for the thousands of birds which had been flying about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

column2: Hansel kept saying to Grethel, "We will soon find the way;" but they did not, and they walked the whole night long and the next day, but still they did not come out of the wood; and they got very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but the berries which they found upon the bushes.
column3: Hansel kept saying to Grethel, "We will soon find the way;" but they did not, and they walked the whole night long and the next day, but still they did not come out of the wood; and they got very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but the berries which they found upon the bushes.

column2: Soon they were so tired that they could not drag themselves along, then they lay down under a tree and again went to sleep.

column2: It was now the third morning since they had left their father's house, and they still walked on; but they only got deeper, and deeper, and deeper into the wood, and Hansel felt that if help did not come very soon they must die of hunger.
column3: It was now the third morning since they had left their father's house, and they still walked on; but they only got deeper, and deeper, and deeper into the wood, and Hansel felt that if help did not come very soon they must die of hunger.

column2: As soon as it was noon they saw a beautiful, snow-white bird sitting upon a bough, singing so sweetly that they stood still and listened to it.
column3: As soon as it was noon they saw a beautiful, snow white bird sitting upon a bough, singing so sweetly that they stood still and listened to it.

column2: It soon ceased, and spreading its wings flew off; and they followed it until it arrived at a cottage, upon the roof of which it perched; and when they went close up to it they saw that the cottage was made of bread and cakes, and the window-panes were of clear sugar.
column3: It soon ceased, and spreading its wings flew off; and they followed it until it arrived at a cottage, upon the roof of which it perched; and when they went close up to it they saw that the cottage was made of bread and cakes, and the window panes were of clear sugar.

column2: We will go in here, said Hansel, "and have a glorious feast.

column2: I will eat a piece of the roof, and you can eat the window.

column2: Will they not be sweet?" So Hansel reached up and broke a piece off the roof, in order to see how it tasted; while Grethel stepped up to the window and began to bite it.
column3: Will they not be sweet?" So Hansel reached up and broke a piece off the roof, in order to see how it tasted; while Grethel stepped up to the window and began to bite it.

column2: Then a sweet voice called out in the room, "Tip-tap, tip-tap, who knocks at my door?" and the children answered, "The wind, the wind, the child of heaven;" and they went on eating without interruption.
column3: Then a sweet voice called out in the room, "Tip tap, tip tap, who knocks at my door?" and the children answered, "The wind, the wind, the child of heaven;" and they went on eating without interruption.

column2: Hansel thought the roof tasted very nice, and so he tore off a great piece; while Grethel broke a large round pane out of the window, and sat down quite contentedly.

column2: Just then the door opened, and a very old woman, walking upon crutches, came out.
column3: Just then the door opened, and a very old woman, walking upon crutches, came out.

column2: Hansel and Grethel were so much frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands; but the old woman nodding her head, said, "Ah, you dear children, what has brought you here?
column3: Hansel and Grethel were so much frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands; but the old woman nodding her head, said, "Ah, you dear children, what has brought you here?

column2: Come in and stop with me, and no harm shall come to you;" and so saying she took them both by the hand, and led them into her cottage.
column3: Come in and stop with me, and no harm shall come to you;" and so saying she took them both by the hand, and led them into her cottage.

column2: A good meal of milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples and nuts, was spread on the table, and in the back room were two nice little beds, covered with white, where Hansel and Grethel laid themselves down, and were happy as could be.
column3: A good meal of milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples and nuts, was spread on the table, and in the back room were two nice little beds, covered with white, where Hansel and Grethel laid themselves down, and were happy as could be.

column2: The old woman behaved very kindly to them, but in reality she was a wicked old witch who way-laid children, and built the breadhouse in order to entice them in; but as soon as they were in her power she killed them, cooked and ate them, and made a great festival of the day.
column3: The old woman behaved very kindly to them, but in reality she was a wicked old witch who way laid children, and built the breadhouse in order to entice them in; but as soon as they were in her power she killed them, cooked and ate them, and made a great festival of the day.

column2: Witches have red eyes, and cannot see very far; but they have a fine sense of smelling, like wild beasts, so that they know when children approach them.
column3: Witches have red eyes, and cannot see very far; but they have a fine sense of smelling, like wild beasts, so that they know when children approach them.

column2: When Hansel and Grethel came near the witch's house she laughed wickedly, saying, "Here come two who shall not escape me." And early in the morning, before they awoke, she went up to them, and saw how lovingly they lay sleeping, with their chubby red cheeks; and she mumbled to herself, "That will be a good bite." Then she took up Hansel with her rough hand, and shut him up in a little cage with a lattice-door; and although he screamed loudly it was of no use. Grethel came next, and shaking her till she awoke, she said, "Get up, you lazy brat, and fetch some water to cook something good for your brother, who must remain in that stall and get fat; and when he is fat enough I shall eat him." Grethel began to cry, but it was all useless, for the old witch made her do as she wanted.
column3: When Hansel and Grethel came near the witch's house she laughed wickedly, saying, "Here come two who shall not escape me." Then she took up Hansel with her rough hand, and shut him up in a little cage with a lattice door; and although he screamed loudly it was of no use. Grethel came next, and shaking her till she awoke, she said, "Get up, you lazy brat, and fetch some water to cook something good for your brother, who must remain in that stall and get fat; and when he is fat enough I shall eat him." Grethel began to cry, but it was all useless, for the old witch made her do as she wanted.

column2: So a nice meal was cooked for Hansel, but Grethel got nothing else but a crab's claw.
column3: So a nice meal was cooked for Hansel, but Grethel got nothing else but a crab's claw.

column2: Every morning the old witch came to the cage and said, "Hansel, stretch out your finger that I may feel whether you are getting fat." But Hansel used to stretch out a bone, and the old woman, having very bad sight, thought it was his finger, and wondered very much why he did not get fat.
column3: Every morning the old witch came to the cage and said, "Hansel, stretch out your finger that I may feel whether you are getting fat." But Hansel used to stretch out a bone, and the old woman, having very bad sight, thought it was his finger, and wondered very much why he did not get fat.

column2: When four weeks had passed, and Hansel still kept quite lean, she lost all her patience, and would not wait any longer. "Grethel," she cried in a passion, "get some water quickly; be Hansel fat or lean, this morning I will kill and cook him." Oh, how the poor little sister grieved, as she was forced to fetch the water, and fast the tears ran down her cheeks!

column2: Had we only been eaten by the wild beasts in the wood, then we should have died together. But the old witch called out, "Leave off that noise; it will not help you a bit."

column2: Then they began to run, and rushing into the house, they fell upon their father's neck.
column3: Then they began to run, and rushing into the house, they fell upon their father's neck.

column2: He had not had one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; and his wife was dead. Grethel shook her apron, and the pearls and precious stones rolled out upon the floor, and Hansel threw down one handful after the other out of his pocket.
column3: He had not had one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; and his wife was dead. Grethel shook her apron, and the pearls and precious stones rolled out upon the floor, and Hansel threw down one handful after the other out of his pocket.

column2: Then all their sorrows were ended, and they lived together in great happiness.
column3: Then all their sorrows were ended, and they lived together in great happiness.
